1. To be eligible for admission into the program, students must:

  1. Complete two years in the Early Childhood Studies major at California State University Channel Islands (CSUCI) OR earn an Associate Degree for Transfer (AS-T) in Early Childhood Education and/or Child Development at a California Community College BEFORE applying to the Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP) PK-3 Early Childhood Specialist Instruction Credential.
  2. Students who have not completed two years in the Early Childhood Studies major at CSUCI or have completed a transfer program in a major other than Early Childhood Education and/or Child Development may still apply, but cannot complete the degree and credential in four years. Students who are non-ECS or Child Development majors must also complete 24 semester units or the equivalent quarter units of non-remedial, degree-applicable coursework at a regionally accredited institution of higher education in early childhood education and/or child development BEFORE entering the Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP) PK-3 Early Childhood Specialist Instruction Credential.
  3. Transfer students and students currently enrolled at CSUCI must have a GPA of at least 2.67 in order to declare the Bachelor of Arts in Early Childhood Studies Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP) PK-3 Early Childhood Specialist Instruction Credential as their major.
  4. Meet all statutory requirements for entry to the Bachelor of Arts in Early Childhood Studies Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP) PK-3 Early Childhood Specialist Instruction Credential.

1. The following applies to the Language Requirement section below:

1. Students must complete the study of a language other than English through the intermediate-level (for example, through CI's SPAN 202 or 212), or demonstrate equivalent proficiency as approved by the CI Languages faculty. American Sign Language (ASL) courses may not be used to meet this requirement.

2. CI does not currently offer intermediate-level courses in languages other than Spanish. If students plan to meet this requirement by taking these courses in another language, they will need to be completed at other colleges or universities.

1. Requirements for Admission to the Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP) Emphasis:

  1. Students must be accepted into the Teaching Credential program prior to enrolling in the 400-level EDAP courses. Students may apply for admission in the first semester of their junior year after completing 60 units. Please visit the School of Education website for more information about applying to the credential program part of the degree.

2. GPA Requirement: A minimum GPA of 3.0 "B" are required to remain in this Emphasis.

1. The Professional Emphasis is an option for students whose educational or career goals are not met by any of CIs existing degree programs. This program permits students to design a complete interdisciplinary program of study suited to their individual needs. To become a Professional Emphasis major, a student must work with the Liberal Studies Director to prepare a carefully conceived program of study.

2. Planning a major takes time and commitment; considerable thought and discussion are required, since the student is, in effect, proposing that the university support an individually-tailored degree program. It also requires that the student assumes a large portion of the responsibility for their educational choices.

1. GPA Requirement: Students who plan to enter a teaching credential program in California will be required to have a cumulative GPA of 2.67 OR a 2.75 GPA in the last 60 units of their baccalaureate degree to be eligible for admission to the post-baccalaureate credential program.

2. Please visit the School of Education website for more information about applying to the credential program.

3. Required Liberal Studies Concentration: 9 additional units must be taken from one of the following concentrations:

1. Art Concentration

2. Bilingualism and Biliteracy Concentration (Requires upper division courses only)

3. Computer Science Concentration

4. Dance Concentration (Requires upper division courses only)

5. English Concentration (Requires upper division courses only)

6. Ethnic Studies Concentration

7. Health Science Concentration

8. History and Social Science Concentration (Requires upper division courses only)

9. Human Development and Psychology Concentration

10. Mathematics Concentration (Requires upper division courses only)

11. Music Concentration

12. Science Concentration

13. Theater Concentration

4. Lower division courses may be substituted with transferable community college courses. Students should work with their Liberal Studies Faculty Advisor to identify the courses that may be used to meet concentration requirements.

5. Those concentrations that do require or allow lower division courses are listed below:

1. The following applies to the Art Concentration: complete a minimum of 9 units of art courses, at least 6 of the 9 units must be upper division.

2. The following applies to the Computer Science Concentration section below: complete a minimum of 9 units of computer science courses. COMP 105 is required. Students must complete 6 additional units, either lower division or upper division.

3. The following applies to the Ethnic Studies Concentration section below: complete a minimum of 9 units of ethnic studies courses. CHS 160 and 349 are required. Complete 3 additional units of upper division Chicana/o Studies or Black Studies courses.

4. The following applies to the Health Science Concentration section below: complete 9 units of health science courses. HLTH 101 is required. Complete 6 additional units of health science courses, 3 must be upper division.

5. The following applies to the Human Development and Psychology Concentration: complete a minimum of 9 units of psychology courses, at least 6 of the 9 units must be upper division.

6. The following applies to the Music Concentration section below: complete a minimum of 9 units of music courses. MUSIC 161 and MUSIC 332 are required. Complete a minimum 3 upper division units of music courses.

7. The following applies to the Science Concentration: students are strongly encouraged to take courses from at least two different science disciplines (e.g.: biology, chemistry, geology, physics, etc.). Complete a minimum of 9 units of science courses, at least 6 of the 9 units must be upper division.

8. The following applies to the Theater Concentration: complete a minimum of 9 units of theater courses. At least 6 of the 9 units must be upper division courses.

1. The following applies to the Lower Division Requirements section below:

1. CI's Music, B.A. requires students to take MUS 109 for four semesters. Many courses that articulate with MUS 109 vary in units. To complete the Lower Division Requirements for this degree prior to transferring to CI, students should ensure that any course units being transferred for MUS 109 credit add to a minimum of four units. Depending on repeatability restrictions at the community college, students may need to complete additional semesters of MUS 109 at CI. 

2. Grades of C- or better are required (and grades of B or better within the past two semesters are recommended) to be earned in MUS 161, 162, 163, 263, and 264 before moving on to the next course(s) in the lower division sequence.

general_texts:
1. Access the University Catalog for Programs and Degrees, General Education Requirements, and Graduation Requirements at CSUCI.

2. Access the Program Website and Program Information in the University Catalog.

Articulation agreements are subject to change from one academic year to the next. It is recommended to review the applicable department agreement(s) in addition to the major agreement and that students meet with a counselor/academic advisor early and often during their academic career.

1. Transfer students from community colleges must be GE-Certified or additional coursework will be required to meet CSUCI requirements. A maximum of 70 units can be transferred.

2. Students who have successfully completed a Registered Nursing program at a community college will be awarded 20 upper division units for nursing courses completed at the community college upon passing the National Council Licensure Examination (NCLEX) - RN.

3. Admission Requirements:

1. Application - Apply to both the University and the Nursing Program. For more information, see Nursing Program website: https://nursing.csuci.edu/

2. Prerequisite Courses - Specific courses listed in the major below

1. Grade Point Average (GPA) - An overall GPA of 2.5 or greater

3. License - Have, or be eligible to acquire, a valid California Registered Nurse (RN) license.

4. Degree - Be graduate of Board of Registered Nursing (BRN)-approved, pre-licensure degree program from an accredited educational institution.

5. Insurance/Health Clearance - Students in the nursing program required to have health insurance, demonstrate a sufficient immunization record consistent with that required of clinical placement in local health care agencies, and pass a physical examination.

6. Background Check/Drug Screening - Criminal background check and drug screening must be completed before clinical placement.

4. Special Grade Requirement: Nursing majors must attain grades of "C" or better in all courses.

5. For the B.S.N. Nursing major only, courses satisfying the CSU American Institutions Requirement are allowed to double-count with the General Education Area D (GE area 4) requirement.

2. For information about the application process for the nursing program, please visit their website at https://nursing.csuci.edu, or email them at nursing@csuci.edu.

3. Special Grade Requirement: Nursing majors must attain grades of "C" or better in all courses.

4. For the Nursing, B.S.N. major only, courses satisfying the CSU American Institutions Requirement are allowed to double-count with the General Education Area D (GE area 4) requirement.

1. POLS 150 satisfies the U.S. Constitution, and California State and Local Government portions of the CSU American Institutions requirement.

1. POLS 140 satisfies the California State and Local Government portion of the CSU American Institutions requirement for students who have taken a college-level, American Government course without a California component, or who have earned Advanced Placement (AP) US Government & Politics Exam credit.

2. 18 units required.

3. Upper division course options in this section are available to take after transferring to CI.

1. The following applies to the Lower Division Requirements sections below:

1. Students who enter the SETI program with the equivalent of first-year, college-level Spanish in high school or a community college may have satisfied the SPAN 101 and SPAN 102 requirement. For more information, see the SETI Program Faculty Advisor or the following webpages:

1. AP, CLEP, IB, and U.S. Military Service Credit: https://www.csuci.edu/registrar/transfer-credit-resources/external-exams.htm

2. For placement guidelines: http://spanish.csuci.edu/plcguidcorsdesc.htm

2. Students must complete one series (6 units) of second-year Spanish courses, either SPAN 201 and 202 or SPAN 211 and SPAN 212. Heritage speakers are encouraged to enroll in SPAN 211 and SPAN 212. Higher level speakers may begin at SPAN 301 or SPAN 302 with faculty advisor approval.
